awd_titl_txt: ABI Development: Building advanced numerical simulation technology for the lake ecology community
awd_abstract_narration:
There are millions of lakes on Earth, many of which are used for recreation, fisheries, and tourism. To effectively manage these lakes, resource managers and scientists must be able to recreate and predict complex physical, chemical, and biological interactions. Computer models are a means of transforming observational data into useable output that recreates historical changes and informs lake and reservoir management. Future scenarios of landscape and atmospheric changes can also be tested to provide forecasting of water quality. Using an open-source computer model, scientists and managers from around the world, students in the classroom, and lake-associations can visualize complex physical and biological data and communicate the relevance of environmental change. 

This project will develop the General Lake Model-Aquatic EcoDynamics (GLM-AED) model, which has been used by specialists in science and management applications, into robust, easy to use software that meets the demands of the broader ecological community for research, education, and outreach. Currently there is a gap between training and adoption, due to the excessive time investment needed to setup and run a GLM-AED simulation. This project will overcome these obstacles by developing new documentation and datasets, tutorials, and user tools, as well as module development and a multi-platform test harness. GLM-AED development will be linked to two research initiatives that showcase how GLM-AED can advance our biological understanding of lakes and reservoirs. These are the modeling of lake ice duration across the continent of North America, and modeling of phosphorus retention across a series of lakes in the Midwest and Northeast of the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This ABI Development: Building advanced numerical simulation technology for the lake ecology community project successfully developed the General Lake Model (GLM) model, which has been used by specialists in lake science and management applications, into robust, easy to use software to meet the demands of the broader ecological community for research, education, and outreach. We (1) published software tools that facilitate and ease model application, (2) trained users and students in theory and practical aspects of running GLM, (3) built a global GLM community through the use of the networking software, and (4) publishing scientific studies to underscore GLM’s performance for simulating fluid dynamics and water quality.

Intellectual Merit:

To underscore GLM’s ability to perform highly as a state-of-the-art lake model, we used GLM in several scientific papers. GLM was used to assess lake phenology and water quality changes, and for mixing dynamics in multi-model ensemble studies. GLM input data was further used as model driver in regional metabolism modeling studies, future climate change projections, and for a global climate change impact assessment in the Inter-Sectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project. GLM was incorporated as an essential 1D model in the workflow of the Inter-Sectoral Impact Model Intercomparison Project (ISIMIP), which ensures the use of its model output in future studies by international colleagues, as well as underscores the model’s performance.

Broader Impacts:

 Software: The open-source package LakeEnsemblR was published in 2020, which allows facilitation of five different vertical 1D hydrodynamic lake models, the calibration of each model, the quantification of uncertainty as well as the visualization of results. This project ensured that GLM is available as an executable and R-package on Windows, Linux and macOS through the release and update of the GLM3r package. By including GLM into LakeEnsemblR, its potential user base and popularity among lake modeling tools increased, which is highlighted by multiple scientific publications. To ease modeling and post-processing, we also published new functions for data visualization and automatic calibration of GLM in the R-package glmtools.

Education and training: We hosted workshops at international conferences and meetings about lake modeling with a special focus on GLM. We also taught a full-semester graduate seminar on lake modeling using GLM in 2019 at UW-Madison. Lastly, we supported graduate students in attending the GLEON all-hands meeting in 2022.

Community and networking: We helped found the Hacking Limnology virtual event series (https://aquaticdatasciopensci.github.io), which hosted virtual workshops and summits from 2021-2023. Through these events, international participants can join free, virtual, workshops and live coding events about aquatic ecosystem modeling, remote sensing, data science and machine learning. About 600 people registered every year for Hacking Limnology. Lastly, the public GLM Slack channel is an active platform for discussions and questions aimed on novice users as well as experienced modelers.
